p.s: Worne uses informal language to clear out his point.
For example he takes words like can't, won't, don't (l. 1) or Cobblers (l. 15) which are informal language.
With this choose of language type he can build a bond with the readers.
Besides he also uses direct adressaddress like in line 1 our, line 32 parents of the UK or line 33 we.
Strengthens the bond between the readers and the author and gives the readers more trust in the author.
Worne also makes use of a metaphor.
For example, on the menu (l. 6) which means that more languages are teached in primary school.
A metaphor can be used to keep the readers thinking about the topic.
moreover there is a simile in line 9-10.
With a simile the author can show better how something is (big, small, etc.).
Furthermore the use of irony like in line 12-15 keeps the readers reading and symphathizessympathizes the author.
A parallelism like in line 16 and 17 can be used to clear out the point of view, because in some way it can also be a repetition which burns in your head so you do not forget the point.
Also the author makes use of a an enumeration and an increasing enumeration.
For example in l. 1 can't, won't, don't and line 17 trade, [...] national security.
With an enumeration the author can illustrate his point better.
Further the author lists a source.
For example in line 19 CBI [...] survey.
Makes the author way more serious and gives also more trust.
The author starts his article with his point of view.
Further he lists some facts/examples and pro- and contra arguments.
He does this changeable.
In the end he makes a request to the parents that they need to do something together against the problem.
To summarize the author makes use of different stylistic devices to convince the reader of his opinion.
Moreover his argumentation leads to his opinion and is so structured that the reader just remembers the points that the author want you to remember.
